awd_titl_txt: Physical Chemistry of the spatiotemporal regulation of protein function through phosphoinositide domains and gradients
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Arne Gericke and Dr. Qi Wen from Worcester Polytechnic Institute to identify the physicochemical conditions that lead to the clustering of phosphoinositide lipids in complex lipid mixtures and to characterize the membrane association of the phosphatase PTEN with such laterally heterogeneous lipid bilayers.  Lipids are major building blocks of cellular membranes and a subclass of these biomolecules control cellular functions by attracting proteins to distinct cellular sites at specific times. Such lipid mediated signaling events require a high degree of organization in space and time, and deviations from the proper execution of these signaling pathways result in a wide array of cellular dysfunctions. The cellular requirements for the local accumulation of signaling lipids are only beginning to emerge and the mechanisms leading to the time dependent control of these lipid pools need to be determined. The research funded under this proposal will delineate the mechanisms that lead to the formation and maintenance of localized pools and gradients of signaling lipids. Graduate and undergraduate students will receive training in many modern research techniques, including single molecule microscopy. The principal investigator will continue to develop inquiry based middle school science projects and his research group will be involved in a range of STEM outreach activities. 

The impact of the research will be to understand how phosphoinositides, which are minority components of plasma and intracellular membranes, provide spatiotemporal control of protein function. Phosphoinositide gradients have been observed in vivo, however, currently there is no experimental platform available that enables the testing of hypotheses about how these gradients are created and maintained. This grant supports the development of a microfluidic device that will be used to systematically investigate how phosphoinositide gradients are created through the action of phosphoinositide specific kinases and phosphatases and subsequently stabilized by other biomolecules.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Phosphoinositides represent only a small fraction of lipids in cellular membranes, yet their importance for cellular processes cannot be overstated. Phosphoinositides mediate physiological functions by regulating the activity and localization of membrane-associated proteins and thereby, control a broad range of membrane processes. The fine tuning of phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate (PI(4,5)P2) signaling events requires a tight control of PI(4,5)P2 distribution. The research pursued with this grant aimed to investigate phosphoinositide clustering in complex lipid mixtures mimicking the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane (aim 1), to test the hypothesis that phosphoinositide clustering promotes PTEN association (aim 2) and to develop a microfluidic device that allows to create phosphoinositide gradients in a controlled fashion and to investigate their spatiotemporal behavior for a range of lipid compositions and morphologies (aim 3).

Using Langmuir film experiments, we investigated lipid mixtures of PI(4,5)P2 with phosphatidylserine (PS), phosphatidylinositol (PI) or phosphatidylethanolamine (PE). We found PE/PI and PE/PI(4,5)P2 monolayer well mixed but more expanded than the corresponding pure PI and PI(4,5)P2 monolayer. We believe that the hydrogen bond interaction of PE with PI or PI(4,5)P2 leads to an inositol ring orientation that is more space consuming than the inositol ring orientation in the absence of PE. For PI/PI(4,5)P2 monolayer we found a 1:1 mixture of the two lipids to be most condensed, suggesting that this is the preferred stoichiometry for the cluster.

In collaboration with the group of R. Pastor (NIH), we used Langmuir trough experiments to validate all-atom molecular dynamics simulations of PI(4,5)P2 Langmuir films. The MD simulations of our collaborators revealed that interactions preferentially occur between specific cations and phosphate groups (P1, P4, and P5) of the inositol headgroup with better-matched kosmotropic/chaotropic characters. Ca2+ is strongly attracted to P4/P5, while K+ preferentially binds to P1; Na+ interacts with both P4/P5 and P1.Cholesterol had been found to promote PI(4,5)P2 clustering, however, the molecular details of the cholesterol/PI(4,5)P2 interaction were unknown. The MD simulations (validated with Langmuir trough experiments) of PI(4,5)P2/cholesterol Langmuir films revealed that the cholesterol hydroxyl group interacts with the PI(4,5)P2phosphodiester and the hydroxyl groups in the 2- or 6-position of the inositol ring. In comparison to its position in other phospholipid bilayers, this requires the cholesterol to move significantly towards the lipid’s headgroup region.    

The PI(3,4,5)P3 phosphatase PTEN binds with its N-terminal end with high specificity PI(4,5)P2, while its C2 domain binds non-specific electrostatically to PS. We hypothesized that PI can replace PS as the second PTEN binding partner and that PI/PI(4,5)P2 clustering leads to stronger PTEN binding. We were able to show that PI can take the place of PS as the second PTEN lipid binding partner, however, the second part of our hypothesis turned out not to be true because the binding of PTEN to PS/PI(4,5)P2 was as efficient as binding to PI/PI(4,5)P2 mixed bilayers. Using a refined global fit analysis for stopped flow spectrophotometry kinetic data at different PTEN concentrations, we were able to delineate the two step process of PTEN membrane association; the first step is a weak binding to the lipid bilayer via non-specific electrostatic interactions, while the second step is presumably the specific binding of PTEN to PI(4,5)P2.

We developed a method that utilizes a microfluidic gradient generator to create lateral lipid gradients in supported lipid bilayers. This methodology provides freedom of choice with respect to composition as well as shape of the lipid gradient. In addition, the device has the ability to create a protein or bivalent cation gradient in the aqueous phase above the lipid bilayer and to elicit a gradient specific response in the SLB. To show the broad applicability of this microfluidic device, we demonstrated that we can create a phosphoinositide gradient on various length scales, ranging from 2 mm to 50 μm. We further showed that a Ca2+ gradient in the aqueous layer above a mixed phosphatidytlcholine (PC)/PI(4,5)P2 or PC/PS lipid bilayer can elicit gradient specific anionic lipid/Ca2+ domain formation. The method provides unprecedented access to study the dynamics and mechanics of protein-lipid interactions on membranes with micron level gradients.

 Broader Impact

            The PI and his group developed and taught a summer camp for middle school aged children with the general topic of surface-active compounds and lipid membranes. We participated in several outreach events with hands-on activities, e.g., WPI’s science fair TouchTomorrow and MassBioFutures high school visits. The PI mentored undergraduate student groups in the development of project-based science projects for middle school students. In addition to training undergraduate and graduate students in the PI’s lab, two undergraduate students were funded through this grant to conduct research at collaborator’s labs in Germany.
